name.text: 38.1.2.1 Mean and Variance of a Continuous Distribution

questiontext.text:
Mean and Variance of a Continuous Distribution

You will probably have realised by now that, essentially, the definitions of discrete and continuous random variables are virtually the same provided we use the analogues given in the following table:


Quantity Discrete Variable Continuous Variable
Probability \(\text{P}(X=x)\) \(f(x) \; dx\)
Allowed Values \(\text{P}(X =x) \geq 0 \) \(f(x) \geq 0\)
Summation \(\displaystyle{\sum \text{P}(X=x)} \) \(\displaystyle{\int} f(x) \; dx\)
Expectation \(\text{E}(X)= \displaystyle{\sum x\text{P}(X=x)}\) ?
Variance \(\text{V}(X) = \displaystyle{\sum(x-\text{E}(X))^2\text{P}(X=x)}\) ?


Completing the above table of analogues to write down the mean and variance of a continuous variable leads to the obvious definitions given in the following Key Point:

Key Point 

Let \(X\) be a continuous random variable with associated pdf \(f(x)\). Then its expectation and variance denoted by \(E[X]\) (or \(\mu\)) and \(V[X]\) (or \(\sigma^2\) ) respectively are given by: \[\text{E}(X)=\displaystyle{\int}_{-\infty}^{\infty} x f(x) \; dx\] and \[\text{V}(X) =\displaystyle{\int}_{-\infty}^{\infty} (x-\text{E}(X))^2 f(x) \; dx = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^2f(x) \; dx -\text{E}(X)^2. \]


As with discrete random variables the variance \(V[X]\) can be written in an alternative form, more amenable to calculation:\[\text{V}(X) = \text{E}(X^2)-\text{E}(X)^2\] where \[\text{E}(X^2)= \displaystyle{\int}_{-\infty}^{\infty} x^2f(x) \; dx.\]
